Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Mechanistic Studies of Hydrodeoxygenation of Lignin-Derived Aromatic Oxygenates over Bimetallic Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1508048
Vohs, John M.

Bio-refining of lignin-based biomass results in production of oxygenated aromatic compounds that must be further processed by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) to produce higher-value aromatic compounds. The study will involve molecular-level investigation of the adsorption and reaction of several oxygenated aromatics on bimetallic catalysts ranging from single crystals to supported catalysts. The resulting insight will aid the discovery and development of catalysts that convert oxygenated aromatic compounds to useful fuels and chemicals. The work will also train students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels in skills relevant to the realization of a sustainable energy and environmental future.

Bimetallic catalysts composed of a group-10 metal (Ni, Pd, Pt) and a second more oxyphilic metal, such as Fe or Zn, will be chosen based on previous demonstration of HDO activity in aldehyde and aldose HDO. Specifically, the proposal will investigate how changes in the metal d-band resulting from the addition of a second more oxyphilic metal (e.g., Fe or Zn) influence the interaction of aromatic rings with the catalyst surface and the role this plays in decreasing overall activity for undesirable ring hydrogenation. The study will also examine the role of the oxyphilic metal in providing specific binding sites for the oxygen atoms in the aromatic oxygenates and the role of these sites in facilitating C-O bond cleavage in HC=O, C-OH, and C-O-C groups. In addition to the single crystal studies, high-surface-area supported bimetallic catalysts will be prepared and subjected to spectroscopic characterization of adsorbed species, and evaluated in a gas-phase flow-reactor to obtain reaction kinetics and selectivity to desired products.

The proposal clearly addresses a critical step (HDO) in the overall biomass refining scheme. As such, it will provide fundamental insight that will aid the development of biomass refining schemes and thereby move lignocellulosic biomass conversion closer to an economically realizable process, with attendant benefits for renewable energy and chemicals. The project will also train both graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of energy conversion, heterogeneous catalysis, and reaction engineering - skills highly sought by the U.S. petrochemical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biomass has potential as a carbon-neutral feedstock for producing liquid fuels and chemicals. For this potential to be realized, however, more efficient catalytic process for its conversion into useful products are needed. This project has provided insight that will help in attaining this goal. In particular, we studied how surface modifiers alter the activity and selectivity of Pt-based catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of aromatic oxygenates derived from the lignin fraction of biomass, which is a critical step in biomass upgrading.

Using a combination of kinetics studies with high surface area catalysts and detailed characterization of the adsorption and reaction of model compounds on single crystal metal surfaces we were able to identify the mechanism by which both metal and metal oxide surface promoters affect the activity of Pt-based catalysts for the HDO lignin-derived molecules, such as guaiacol, anisole, and cresol, and direct the selectivity toward high value aromatic hydrocarbons. The most important observations were the following; on Pt-only surfaces aromatic rings were found to bond strongly to the surface resulting in a lay flat adsorption geometry that promotes hydrogenation of the aromatic ring under typical HDO reaction conditions; and decorating the Pt surface with a second more oxophilic metal (i.e. one that bonds oxygen more strongly than Pt) such as Zn and Co, was found to produce catalysts that were highly selective for the production of aromatic oxygenates. These modifiers were found to affect reactivity in two ways. First, through an electronic interaction with the Pt, they decrease the interaction energy of the aromatic ring with the Pt surface, and second they provide a bonding site for the oxygen functionality in the reactant molecule. Combined, these two effects produce an upright bonding geometry on the surface which facilitates selective cleavage of the C-O bond. Oxide modifiers, such as WOx and NbOx were found to operate in a similar way, with interactions at the Pt-oxide interface playing the important role of helping to maintain the oxide in a partially-reduced state with exposed undercoordinated cations which again provide binding sites for the oxygen functionality in the targeted reactant molecules.  We believe these insights will aid in the design of highly active and selective heterogeneous catalysts for use in processes designed for the upgrading of biomass into liquid fuels and chemicals.

In addition to these new scientific insights, this project has also had the broader impact of training both graduate and undergraduate students in an important area of chemical engineering, catalysis and reaction engineering, and providing them with the expertise that will allow them to be leaders in the development of new technologies that decrease our reliance on fossil fuels and help mitigate the deleterious effects of their usage, such as global warming.
